image.altText: A woman with windswept, dark hair wearing a black coat and white blouse turns a street corner with autumn foliage.

props.synopsis: A three day hearing has begun in northern Tasmania against a former Tasmanian government MP and Miss Australia who has been accused of punching her ex-partner in the face and verbally abusing him for almost a decade.

title.children: Hearing begins into alleged emotional abuse by former Labor politician

image.altText: Dozens of hens with glossy brown feathers and red plump combs under a clear blue sky.

props.synopsis: A deadly strain of avian influenza wreaking havoc in Victoria is yet to make its way to Tasmania, keeping the state bird flu free. But Biosecurity Tasmania warns it won't stay this way forever, and is urging the state's agricultural industry to be extra vigilant.

title.children: Can Tasmania keep its birds safe from a deadly bird flu?

image.altText: Kerry Reece and her husband Brendan sit at the kitchen table looking at insurance bills

props.synopsis: Kerry Reece has been loyal to her insurer for decades, but a new class action claims her loyalty might not have been rewarded — rather it has seen the bills of customers like her inflated, lawyers are alleging.

title.children: Insurance giant accused of using computer program to inflate premiums of loyal customers

image.altText: A side profile close up of Peter Dutton.

props.synopsis: Peter Dutton's political survival as an opposition leader thus far is an impressive feat, but the issue of nuclear power could be one that damages his popularity with women, a new piece of research shows.

title.children: Peter Dutton's a political freak of nature, but is he about to nuke himself with women voters?

image.altText: "Leased" sign outside house

props.synopsis: Rental affordability in Australians capital cities is going from bad to worse. PropTrack's latest Market Insight Report shows surging rents over the past year have seen the number of affordable rentals "vanishing" across the country.

title.children: Catch 22 means 'pretty much no rental properties are affordable' in Australia

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: After days of discussions about gun reform in the wake of her father killing two Perth women, Ariel Bombara cut through the noise with her simple message — that nothing short of a massive system overhaul would've stopped the tragedy.

title.children: Ariel Bombara fronted the media with courage and a simple message about her father's murderous actions

image.altText: Wide shot of the six people at the top sail of the Sydney Opera House. A "No War" slogan is painted is painted in red in caps.

props.synopsis: Twenty-one years since the historic Opera House "NO WAR" protest, the men behind the handiwork have revealed how they pulled off — and how they view it now a new war is waged in the Middle East.

title.children: The faces and fallout of Australia's 'NO WAR' Opera House protest

image.altText: A man leans on crutches surrounded by debris from a damaged tent camp

props.synopsis: Officials on the ground in Gaza say that at least 12 of the people killed were women. The Israeli army denied it struck the area.

title.children: Second tent strike in Rafah kills 21 people, Israel denies involvement

image.altText: Woman holding calculator surrounded by documents and keyboard on desk.

props.synopsis: While the cost of living crisis continues in Australia, there is some relief on its way from July.

title.children: If you're feeling too scared to spend money right now, some relief is on the way

image.altText: A photo of people digging at the site of a landslide.

props.synopsis: The landslide that struck Papua New Guinea's Enga province came without apparent warning and while people slept. But can landslides be predicted? The answer could help prevent future deaths.

title.children: Why it's a massive task to rescue those buried in the PNG landslide

image.altText: Two pictures, side by side. One shows Julian Assange looking through a window. The other shows Donald Trump at a microphone.

props.synopsis: The Republican presidential candidate was asked about the Australian WikiLeaks founder, who is fighting extradition to the US, during an interview for a podcast.

title.children: Trump says he'd seriously consider pardoning Julian Assange if re-elected

image.altText: Torres Strait cuisine graphic

props.synopsis: At her local supermarket, Evelyn Billy looked around and saw food from all cultures — except hers.

title.children: 'One deadly menu': The food mission to bring First Nations cuisine to all of Australia

image.altText: Cold Chisel band members stand in front of a deep orange backdrop. Five men standing in a row.

props.synopsis: Cold Chisel is hitting the road for a national tour to celebrate their golden musical anniversary.

title.children: 'The Big Five-O': Cold Chisel announces huge 50th anniversary tour

image.altText: A portrait of Virginia Gay, a white woman with curly blonde hair, wearing a lace black bra and cropped suit jacket.

props.synopsis: Before this year's Archibald finalists are announced, we speak to a former finalist about all things portraiture — from choosing a sitter to adding the final touches.

title.children: We asked a seven-time Archibald finalist how to paint a portrait

image.altText: Close up shot of hands and paperwork.

props.synopsis: An independent review of legal service funding has found that current levels are insufficient to meet Australia's legal assistance needs, especially help for marginalised groups.

title.children: 'Government has treated service providers like sporting clubs': Legal services can't meet Australia's needs

image.altText: Alex De Minaur

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur sees off his American opponent as wet and cold conditions play havoc at the French Open.

title.children: De Minaur endures long delay and torrid conditions to make light work of American teen at French Open

image.altText: Men use long sticks to lift a large boulder in thick, wet mud looking strained

props.synopsis: Concerns about a second landslide are compounded by worries about the possible outbreak of disease at the site.

title.children: 'The rocks keep falling': Warnings of another landslide prompt evacuation orders in Papua New Guinea

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to fall in morning trade ahead of the latest ABS inflation data, while the Nasdaq rises above 17,000 points for the first time ever. Follow live.

title.children: ASX to fall ahead of inflation data, Nasdaq hits record high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Renters facing 'crisis conditions' as the number of 'affordable' homes plummets
Inflation tipped to fall to 3.4pc in April
IAG will defend class action, filed by customers who argue they were misled about premiums

image.altText: A man wears a small white gourd shaped hat on his head with one hand up.

props.synopsis: The pope used the term during a closed-door meeting with Italian bishops on May 20.

title.children: 'Never intended to offend': Pope Francis apologises for using homophobic Italian term

image.altText: A patron a concert holds a shard of glass up to a protester at the front of a concert.

props.synopsis: Tensions flare at a Hobart concert after pro-Palestinian protesters disrupted the performance of Jewish singer-songwriter Deborah Conway, with one audience member smashing a wine glass on the stage and holding the shattered stem towards the face of an activist.

title.children: Deborah Conway concert flares as patron threatens pro-Palestinian protester with broken wine glass

image.altText: A young blonde woman named Ariel Bombara sitting while being interviewed.

props.synopsis: The daughter of Mark James Bombara, who shot and killed Jennifer and Gretl Petelczyc in their Floreat home, says police were warned about her father's disturbing behaviour.

title.children: Daughter of Perth killer warned police three times he was an 'imminent threat'

image.altText: A young boy smiles broadly at the camera, while siting outside on elevated wooden decking. Grass and sunshine are in the backg

props.synopsis: Early education can have a huge impact on a child's path in life, but some kids are missing out. These experts say that needs to change, and they know how to do it.

title.children: Child care changes lives. So why are some families held back from accessing it?

image.altText: rows of solar panels on a block of land in an aerial view, green land surrounds them

props.synopsis: With upheavals in the agriculture industry making some farms unviable, a landowner in South Australia is encouraging others to consider repurposing their properties for renewable energy projects.

title.children: Regional property owners turning unusable land into money through solar energy leases

image.altText: A young woman smiling

props.synopsis: Aboriginal suicides in hospitals and anger over Victoria's efforts to Close the Gap are raised as the Yoorrook Justice Commission begins its new inquiry into health, housing and education.

title.children: Death of young Aboriginal woman at Melbourne hospital raised during truth-telling hearings

image.altText: A man poses in a New South Wales jersey before a State of Origin game

props.synopsis: When they talk about players being made for Origin they're talking about Cam McInnes, and the belated New South Wales debutant is striving to make his mark for his state.

title.children: Missing teeth and broken knees — how rugby league's unbreakable man is ready to prove he's made for Origin

image.altText: Forensic officers search inside bins at a crime scene

props.synopsis: A woman has been arrested after a man was allegedly stabbed and killed in a home in Sydney's eastern beaches.

title.children: A man has died after being allegedly stabbed in a home in Sydney's eastern beaches

image.altText: An older man in a cap sits outdoors in his wheelchair with his dog.

props.synopsis: In less than six years Queensland Health has been forced to pay out more than $390 million to more than 1,000 people injured as a result medical negligence in public hospitals. Michael Stewart was one of them.

title.children: Staggering cost of medical negligence payouts in Queensland revealed as patient fights to return home

image.altText: A knife with fingerprints under a fluorescent light.

props.synopsis: Hidden behind a towering electric fence in a regional Victorian city, a team of 11 forensic scientists is helping police catch criminals. The ABC takes a look inside the secretive, high-tech facility.

title.children: 'We're not as fast as CSI': Inside the high-security forensic hub helping Victoria Police solve crimes

image.altText: beef packaged in Japan

props.synopsis: On a recent visit to Tokyo, a New South Wales farmer was shocked to find Australian beef selling for less than you can find it in Coles and Woolworths.

title.children: 'It shows there is gouging': Farmer finds Australian beef selling cheaper in Japanese supermarket

image.altText: A close-up of a young person's face.

props.synopsis: Alana Tiller has around 3 per cent vision "on a good day" and wouldn't change it. She's among young advocates hoping for change in the way people talk about vision impairments.

title.children: 'It's something you can love about yourself': Why vision-impaired Australians want you to think twice about your assumptions

image.altText: A woman in hijab covers her face as she walks through a crowd and smoke

props.synopsis: The UN Security Council has scheduled emergency meeting on the situation in Rafah after Israeli air strikes killed 45 people and wounded dozens more.

title.children: As an investigation into the air strike on civilians in Rafah begins, here are some of the key events leading up to the attack

image.altText: A silver box with an intricate etching.

props.synopsis: Few people have ever heard Wu-Tang Clan's legendary seventh studio album. That's because only a single copy was ever made and the masters were destroyed. But visitors to the Mona gallery in Hobart will get a chance.

title.children: It's the most expensive album in history and few people in the world have heard it. Now, it's coming to Tassie

image.altText: A man, woman and three young children walk down a street carrying bags and backpacks, youngest child sits in a pram

props.synopsis: Israel has pounded Rafah with air strikes and tank fire, pressing its offensive in the southern Gaza city despite international condemnation of an attack that sparked a blaze in a tent camp for the displaced, killing at least 45 people.

title.children: Penny Wong urges Israel to end Rafah offensive as Israeli forces reportedly reach city's centre

image.altText: James Marape salutes as he walks past defence personnel outside parliament house.

props.synopsis: As one of Papua New Guinea's remote villages grapples with one of the worst natural disasters in its history, the prime minister is busy attending to his own political crisis.

title.children: A king and a US president sent their condolences to PNG. But where is the nation's own prime minister?

image.altText: A man lays against the wall of a car park.

props.synopsis: Welcome to Portland, Oregon, the US city that decriminalised drugs and nearly immediately regretted it.

title.children: This progressive US state pioneered a radical drug policy, then overdose deaths skyrocketed
